title: Can I take the person who placed a restraining order on me to small claims court for debts we owe together currently?
question: She placed a restraining order on me, which I am going to fight, but in the mean time we have a debt/loan in both of our names, can I take her to small claims or would that break the order? Would I get in trouble?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Restraining order and criminal defense,Lawsuits and disputes,Summons and complaint,Court basics,Small claims court,General Practice
answers:
Simiple:

When you go to court to fight the restraining order ask the judge if he/she is going to continue the restraining order to carve out the exception for you to bring a small claims action against her for the money she owes. The judge can order an exception to the order at the hearing.

Be careful on how you proceed, even with the order to make sure you don't violate it and end up in trouble. Many times judges will continue the restraining order, even if not warranted, just to make the party bringing the action feel comfortable.

Good luck with your situation.

Matthew Williamson

If you were going to sue this person through a lawyer, I'd say no problem. However, since it is small claims court, where lawyers aren't involved and you would be acting as your own attorney, I would put the matter on hold, if possible, until you've resolved the restraining order issues.

You are entitled to exercise your legal rights, but the restraining order most likely says you are to have no contact with this person. Even sending the person a summons and complaint might be considered contact. (Of course, the summons would have to be served by a third party, since you can't serve legal documents in your own case.)

If it looked like the lawsuit was an attempt to harass the other person, instead of resolving a legitimate legal dispute, you could also find yourself in big trouble.

If you must move quickly on this issue -- for instance, if the statute of limitations to sue is about to run -- I would ask the judge for clarification at the next court hearing on the restraining order.

Restraining order matters can be very tricky. You may want to hire a lawyer to represent you... and advise you on whether your should proceed with a lawsuit at this time.
